plant.description:
Brief Description (Appearance, Habitat, and Where Commonly Found)
• Appearance: Tomato plants feature green foliage (leaves and stems) that emit a distinct, pungent aroma and are covered with prickly hairs4. The plant produces fruit that begins as green and unripe, eventually maturing into the popular fleshy, red tomatoes56.
• Habitat and Where Commonly Found: As a widely accepted and cultivated food crop, tomato plants are most commonly found growing in agricultural settings, household gardens, and in pots on patios or balconies

toxins.name: Glycoalkaloids, specifically tomatine and solanine
toxins.description:
in cats: These compounds act as cytotoxins and neurotoxins that disrupt a cat's body in three primary ways25:
    ◦ Cytotoxic Cell Destruction: The toxins interact with the phospholipids of the cell membranes, increasing their permeability and causing the cells to be destroyed5. This causes significant damage to the intestinal epithelial cells, resulting in severe gastrointestinal inflammation and irritation5.
    ◦ Neurological Overstimulation: The toxins inhibit acetylcholinesterase, a crucial enzyme in the brain responsible for breaking down acetylcholine6. This inhibition leads to a dangerous overstimulation of the parasympathetic nervous system6.
    ◦ Mitochondrial Impairment: The glycoalkaloids disrupt the energy balance of the cells by inhibiting the cellular respiratory chain
toxins.concentration_notes: The concentration of these toxins is exceptionally high in the green, vegetative parts of the plant (leaves and stems) as well as in the unripe, green fruit1.... As the tomato ripens and turns red, the toxin levels drop significantly to negligible amounts; ripe red tomatoes are largely harmless to cats, though consuming them in large quantities may still cause mild irritation1.... Furthermore, cats are much more sensitive to these toxins than dogs because feline livers lack the specific glucuronidation pathways needed to efficiently detoxify them, leading to prolonged and more severe poisoning

toxins.name: Atropine
toxins.description: in cats: The provided sources do not detail the specific biological mechanism of action for the atropine found in tomato plants
toxins.concentration_notes: Atropine is noted to be present in tomatoes, but it is considered a "lesser toxin" compared to the highly concentrated tomatine

symptoms.name: Hypersalivation (Drooling)
symptoms.onset: Within a few hours of ingestion.
symptoms.notes:
This is typically one of the first signs of oral and gastrointestinal irritation caused by the plant's glycoalkaloid toxins.
2. Vomiting and Diarrhea

symptoms.name: Vomiting and diarrhea
symptoms.onset: Within a few hours of ingestion.
symptoms.notes:
Solanine and tomatine act as direct gastrointestinal irritants. If the vomiting or diarrhea is severe, it can lead to dehydration.
3. Lethargy and Weakness

symptoms.name: Lethargy, weakness, and confusion
symptoms.onset: Progresses after gastrointestinal signs (usually within a few to several hours).
symptoms.notes:
This is caused by the systemic absorption of solanine, which acts as a cholinesterase inhibitor and depresses the central nervous system.
4. Dilated Pupils (Mydriasis)

symptoms.name: Dilated pupils (mydriasis)
symptoms.notes:
This is an additional neurological effect stemming from the disruption of the nervous system by the glycoalkaloid toxins.
5. Slowed Heart Rate (Bradycardia)

symptoms.name: Slowed heart rate (bradycardia)
symptoms.onset: Occurs after the systemic absorption of a large toxic dose.
symptoms.notes: Severe cardiovascular and neurological effects are rare in cats. Felines typically do not consume enough of the unpalatable green plant material to trigger life-threatening symptoms, but it remains a risk in cases of severe poisoning.

treatments.name: Oxygen Therapy, Defibrillation, and Anticonvulsant Therapy
treatments.description: The veterinary team will secure the airway to provide oxygen supplementation or mechanical ventilation, administer anticonvulsants (like benzodiazepines or barbiturates) to stop seizures, and use defibrillation if the heart experiences ventricular fibrillation
treatments.notes:
This is the most urgent, life-saving intervention but is only required in the most severe, critical poisoning cases where the glycoalkaloids have progressed to cause respiratory depression, circulatory failure, or severe neurological impairment23.
2. Gastrointestinal Decontamination

treatments.name: Emesis Induction or Gastric Lavage
treatments.description: The veterinarian will medically induce vomiting (often using xylazine for cats) to empty the stomach. Alternatively, they may perform a gastric lavage (pumping the stomach) under anesthesia
treatments.notes:
This step is crucial for eliminating the toxic green plant parts or unripe fruit before the toxins can be absorbed, but it is typically only performed if the ingestion was recent (within 1 to 2 hours) and the cat is not yet showing severe symptoms4.
3. Toxin Binding

treatments.name: Administration of Activated Charcoal
treatments.description: The cat is given a dose of activated charcoal (1–4 g/kg body weight) to bind to any unabsorbed solanine and tomatine remaining in the gastrointestinal tract, preventing the toxins from entering the bloodstream
treatments.notes:
In cases of severe poisoning, the veterinarian may repeat the administration of activated charcoal multiple times at 4- to 6-hour intervals2.
4. Systemic Support and Excretion

treatments.name: Intravenous (IV) Fluid Therapy
treatments.description: Crystalloid IV fluids are administered to rehydrate the cat from fluid loss (due to vomiting and diarrhea), stimulate urine production (diuresis), and promote the excretion of the toxins
treatments.notes:
In advanced poisoning cases where the toxins have caused the destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), the IV infusion rate must be aggressively increased. This ensures adequate blood flow to the kidneys and prevents secondary kidney damage caused by the release of hemoglobin2.
5. Pharmacological Symptom Management

treatments.name: Atropine Administration
treatments.description: The veterinarian administers the medication atropine to help counteract the specific effects of the toxins on the nervous system
treatments.notes: While there is no direct antidote for solanine or tomatine poisoning, atropine is specifically utilized to treat "cholinergic symptoms" caused by the toxins, such as a dangerously slow heart rate (bradycardia) or excessive salivation
